 I do not think suicide is illegal anywhere in the US. Regarding Oregon, I think you are confusing it with assisted suicide for the terminally ill. Attempted suicide is not illegal either, that is why they are not treated like law breakers. They are not sent to a mental institution for mandatory observation. If this person is taken to a medical facility they may possibly be held against their will. In most states, there is something called a two-person hold, where if two doctors deem this person is mentally incapacitated to the point where they feel the patient is a danger to themselves or others they may be held for three days until seen by a judge who then determines what to do. Almost never are they held after that. In most cases, the situation can be calmed down so it never gets to a court. In the case of the attempted suicide, one must determine if they are "actively suicidal", or likely to attempt it again soon. Most often, if there is some support system, they can be discharged to someone else's care. It is now uncommon for folks to be admitted to the psych unit. One reality is that there simply are not that many psych beds any more do to lack of funding.

 I find it interesting that we can at least possibly conceive of suicide as a rational and compassionate solution for those with a merciless terminal illness. We (and I) have argued that depression, however, is not a rational reason to commit suicide, because the negative affect of the disease does not allow the depressed person to think clearly enough to realize that suicide is not the best solution. 
 
 I have seen some people with chronic depression (psychotic and otherwise) who have suffered for years/decades with the disease. Nothing seems to work and they have tried every kind of treatment. Sometimes the treatments are of little or no help. The family suffers, they cannot work, there are multiple suicide attempts. And the person with this unusually severe depression truly suffers; their existence is pitiable. This may not off topic, but this sounds like an incurable (terminal) illness with permanent suffering. I can see how suicide seems rational in some respects. I am not advocating anything here, because there is not a clear line drawn here as there is in, say, metastatic cancer. It's just something I have thought about.

 There almost seems to be a "catch 22" happening where suicidal tendencies are concerned. It seems that someone who wishes to commit suicide is automatically thought of as emotionally unstable, whether or not their decision of suicide was based on calm, rational reasoning. No doubt, someone who is suicidal most likely is finding life miserable, but that does not mean that his/her emotions are out of control or that his/her decisions are irrational. I can fully sympathize with someone who has a very painful and/or debilitating terminal or long term illness wishing to end their suffering. The movie "Million Dollar Baby" comes to mind.
 
 The hard part is to differentiate between those who have chosen suicide because of rational, indisputable reasons, and between those who are simply very depressed and whose suffering could indeed be relieved with counseling and/or anti-depressive drugs (and painkillers, if an illness is to blame). Perhaps it makes sense to force someone who is suicidal to go through treatments against depression and, if they still want to kill themselves after anti-depressants have calmed down the more extreme emotions, then let them. Perhaps someone else might have a better idea...

That question interests me as to why even people who are atheists stand against suicide as a reasonable way for dealing with an unfulfilled life. I wonder why that is.

 
 That is an exceedingly easy question to answer. Atheists believe that you have only one life and no afterlife, therefore they value life much more than someone who does believe in an afterlife.

I think that suicide should be kept illegal as it already is. My reason? Have you ever known the victim's family not to be devastated after he/she killed himself? Suicidal people destroy their family emotionally, causing them great pain. That is against the law.

post_info.post_title: Suicide is illegal for a reason

Suicide is an individual right. A society that tells each member they do not have to care about another individual's welfare should not have suicide illegal. I can barely fathom how people in this society can live with this huge contradiction.

I see suicide as a cowardly act, instead of facing your problems you take the easy way out... Now what? Not only have you devistated you family, but the problem is still there, its just that you no longer have to face it. I realize tht the person may be going through a rough patch, but if you can face it and stand tall all throughout you will have proven yourself the better man.(Or woman)
